prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We select the brightest, strongest mass-losing stars in NGC 1978 and NGC 419. Following Olofsson (2008), the expected flux density of the CO(2-1) and CO(3-2) lines depends on the mass-loss rate (MLR; 10e-6 M_sun/yr), the wind velocity (v_exp; km/s), the abundance of CO to H_2 (f_CO) and the distance to the source (D; kpc) as follows (eq. 1):
S_CO(2-1) = 6 * (MLR^1.2) * ((15/v_exp)^1.6) * ((f_CO/10^-3)^0.7) * ((1/D)^2) Jy
Groenewegen et al. (2007, 2009) estimate the MLRs by modeling the SED and infrared spectra (Fig. 1), assuming a Galactic gas-to-dust ratio and expansion velocity (psi_sun=200, v_exp=10 km/s; Table 1). The resulting flux density of the CO(2-1) line for four different combinations of v_exp and f_CO is listed in Table 2 (assuming the lower of the two MLRs from Groenewegen et al. 2007, 2009). S_CO(3-2) is approximately twice S_CO(2-1). For NGC 1978, we derive f_CO=3e-4, from the oxygen and iron abundances ([O/Fe] = -0.11 and [Fe/H] = -0.4; Mucciarelli et al. 2008). The oxygen abundance for NGC 419 has not been measured, but since [O/Fe] is thought to increase with decreasing metallicity, we assume [O/Fe]=+0.0 so that f_CO=1e-4. In general, mass-loss theory predicts larger velocities and lower values of f_CO at low metallicity. The larger dependence on the velocity in the above equation works in our favor.
Spectral setup: Based on the expected velocities (~10 km/s), we require a spectral resolution near 0.5 km/s. We choose a bandwidth/resolution of 937.5 MHz / 488.3 kHz, corresponding to a velocity resolution of 0.64 km/s in band 6 for CO(2-1) and 0.42 km/s in band 7 for CO(3-2).
Sensitivity: To improve the S/N, we place one spectral window at the CO line frequency and three additional windows on the continuum (we do not expect other spectral lines to be strong enough for detection with ALMA). We target a >4 sigma detection for the CO(2-1) line for the most conservative scenarios listed in Table 2 (#1). However, since the MLRs used to choose the sensitivity here were estimated by radiative transfer modeling of the SEDs, they are subject to uncertainty through the choice of dust optical constants (and may be lower by factors of ~2). We thus round up to the nearest hour of integration, which results in a 3 sigma detection even with a decrease in the MLR by up to 32% for NGC 1978 and 41% for NGC 419 (for scenario #1 in Table 2) with a minimal increase in the total integration time.
The S/N ratios quoted above are lower limits, derived using the most conservative case from Table 2 and using the full velocity resolution. The S/N can be doubled by binning the spectra by a factor of 4, which is easily done with velocities >10 km/s and velocity resolution ~0.5 km/s. This, together with more optimistic combinations of v_exp and f_CO can yield S/N > 10.
For MIR1 in NGC 1978, we request sensitivities of 1.8 mJy and 3.1 mJy in CO(1-2) and CO(3-2), respectively. For MIR1 in NGC 419, we request 3.5 mJy for CO(1-2) and 6 mJy for CO(3-2). The total time requested is 8.0 hrs (6 hrs for NGC 1978 and 2 hrs for NGC 419).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Stellar evolution theory is highly uncertain when it comes to the complicated mass-loss process during the final stages of a star's life, especially for metal-poor stars. Recent advances in infrared telescopes have provided the sensitivity necessary for detecting circumstellar dust formed during the Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) phase for entire populations in metal-poor galaxies. However, without (poorly-constrained) assumptions about the wind properties, it is impossible to use these measurements to arrive at a total gas+dust mass-loss rate (MLR). We propose to observe the CO(3-2) and (2-1) lines in mass-losing carbon-rich AGB stars in NGC1978 and NGC419, clusters in the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds, to directly measure the wind velocities and MLRs. Since these stars are in well-studied clusters, their masses, metallicities, distances, and pulsation periods are known. This information, together with the wind properties, provides a complete picture of this phase of evolution. The results will be directly applicable to stellar evolution theory and to studies of high-redshift galaxies, whose interstellar dust and (rest-frame) infrared flux may be dominated by stars like these.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Goddard Space Flight Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration

The Research School of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Australia National University
Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics, Manchester, University of
Goddard Space Flight Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
Department of Physics and Astronomy, Uppsala University
